title: Artificial Selection in Fruit Flies PC

content.prompt:
A researcher created an experimental chamber that allowed a population of fruit flies to mate randomly, but where female flies had to choose one of three side-chambers in which to lay eggs. All three side-chambers were the same except for the added scent of apple in side-chamber A, banana in side-chamber B, and cucumber in side-chamber C. Only eggs deposited in side-chamber C were allowed to hatch and produce offspring. Adult flies did not know which side-chamber was producing offspring. Every day for 100 days, the researcher counted the number of flies in each side-chamber. By day 100, the number of flies in side-chamber C greatly increased, while the number of flies in side-chambers A and B had greatly decreased.

Which of the following statements best explains why there were more flies in side-chamber C, than in side-chambers A or B, on day 100?

choices.label: More flies were entering side-chamber C because flies that prefer the scent of cucumber were artificially selected for.
More flies were entering side-chamber C because female flies learned which side-chamber allowed for successful reproduction.
More flies were entering side-chamber C because female fruit fly offspring produced in side-chambers A and B were less fit for the environment.
More flies were entering side-chamber C because male fruit fly offspring produced in side-chambers A and B were less fit for the environment.
